+0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5dcae06c7eece5354445b7e4?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"adf8ac231b4b36712ba6412fb748f0ef","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn76@2020_2/2020/10/09/03-33-23-085_0cf8a7129e574b4e.webp","destWidth":2399,"destHeight":1799,"sourceBytes":114468,"destBytes":114468,"author":"insider@insider.com (Dave Johnson)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f7f5ee10f9900001939ee55?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn3@2020_4/2020/10/09/03-33-30-758_57058064fad5cbd4.webp","https://i.insider.com/5dcadcbe3afd37286b11c2c5?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn93@2020_1/2020/10/09/03-33-26-933_52518d21f301c61d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=rpw24QHswRc:XoEtSmoGKYI:F7zBnMyn0Lo":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=rpw24QHswRc:XoEtSmoGKYI:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn42@2020_2/2020/10/09/03-33-33-240_1dc84790e35d179e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn41@2020_4/2020/10/09/03-33-30-246_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=rpw24QHswRc:XoEtSmoGKYI:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn76@2020_2/2020/10/09/03-33-24-415_e5e1efb486d373b4.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/rpw24QHswRc":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn11@2020_6/2020/10/09/03-33-24-688_4e77f990f9eafff7.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602214360907},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:32:40","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:32:40","title":"The last time Trump said he tested negative for COVID-19 was in May, and the White House refuses to say if he's tested negative since","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/white-house-wont-say-when-trump-was-last-tested-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7f6d804c3b2e0019bb9fc6?format=jpeg\" alt=\"trump covid test swab\" height=\"1249\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>President Donald Trump on June 5.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Nicholas Kamm/Getty</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The White House has repeatedly refused to disclose when President Donald Trump last tested negative for COVID-19.</li>\n<li>The last time Trump or anyone at the White House said on the record that the president tested negative was on May 21.</li>\n<li>It's unclear how frequently Trump has been tested since, and he has repeatedly flouted coronavirus precautions by holding public events with large crowds.</li>\n<li>When a White House spokesman was asked when Trump was last tested and if he could specify any results between May 21 and Trump's positive test on October 2, he said \"the president is tested regularly.\"</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Despite the seismic implications of the president of the US contracting a deadly and highly infectious disease with no cure, the White House is still providing very little basic information about President Donald Trump's coronavirus status.</p><p>Aside from his positive-test announcement on Friday — which led to him being hospitalized with COVID-19 for three nights — the last time Trump was on the record talking about taking a test was in May, when he <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-says-he-tested-positively-toward-negative-for-coronavirus-2020-5\">said</a>, \"I tested positively toward negative.\"</p><p>Between Trump's \"positively toward negative\" disclosure on May 21 and the tweet confirming he had tested positive for COVID-19 on October 2, the White House would not point Insider toward any specific instances when Trump even took a test.</p><p>At one point in July, White House press secretary Kayleigh McEnany said Trump was tested \"<a href=\"https://www.politico.com/news/2020/07/21/trump-tested-coronavirus-multiple-times-day-375957\">multiple times a day</a>.\" <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-contradicts-press-secretary-number-of-times-tested-per-day-2020-7\">He contradicted her later in the day</a> and said he couldn't recall taking more than one in 24 hours.</p><p>McEnany, along with other White House officials, such as spokeswoman Alyssa Farah, have declined to specify when Trump takes coronavirus tests or the last time he tested negative.</p><p>\"I can't reveal that at this time. Doctors would like to keep it private,\" Farah said on Thursday.</p><p>The president attended 113 public events between his last known negative test and the night before he disclosed he had COVID-19, according to <a href=\"https://factba.se/topic/calendar\">a database of his travel and events calendar from Factba.se</a>, a site with a variety of Trump-related databases.</p><p>Insider asked the White House repeatedly on Thursday how often the president is tested, when his last test was, and if it had disclosed any tests taken since May 21.</p><p>\"The president is tested regularly,\" a White House spokesman said in an email.</p><p>He did not respond when asked to specify how frequently the president is tested.</p><h2><strong>Many events, few precautions from Trump</strong></h2><p>Other than the rare occasion when he wears a mask in public, like <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-wears-face-mask-in-public-for-first-time-coronavirus-2020-7\">the first time he did in July</a>, the president has mostly flouted basic public-health precautions. He's also rarely enforced social-distancing rules and mask-wearing at his rallies and other public events.</p><p>Trump's events have varied in size and density, but there have been a few noteworthy examples that posed more risk than others:</p><ul><li><strong>June 20:</strong> Trump returned to in-person campaign rallies after a monthslong pause because of the pandemic, starting in Tulsa, Oklahoma. Two aides who attended <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/2-trump-campaign-staffers-tulsa-rally-tested-positive-covid-19-2020-6\">later tested positive</a>, as did his Republican ally Herman Cain, who <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/herman-cain-dies-after-being-hospitalized-for-covid-19-2020-7\">died from the disease</a> a month later, though it's unclear if he contracted the virus at the event.</li><li><strong>July 4:&#160;</strong>Trump held an <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-july-4-celebration-amid-rising-covid-19-cases-2020-7\">Independence Day celebration</a> with a speech, military flyover, and fireworks in Washington, DC.</li><li><strong>August 27: </strong>The final night of the Republican National Convention saw <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/photos-crowd-maskless-convention-white-house-trump-speech-social-distancing-2020-8\">a crowd of about 1,500 packed together and maskless on the White House South Lawn</a> for Trump's speech accepting his nomination.</li></ul><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;Mark Knoller  (@markknoller) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1299139967646601219?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">August 28, 2020</a></blockquote><script async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><ul><li><strong>September 8:&#160;</strong>Trump at a North Carolina rally <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2020/sep/08/trump-rally-north-carolina-mask\">mocked former Vice President Joe Biden for the social-distancing measures</a> taken at his events.</li><li><strong>September 14: </strong>Trump held his first indoor rally in Nevada, against <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-nevada-indoor-rally-against-advice-supporters-no-masks-2020-9\">the warnings</a> of Gov. Steve Sisolak and local public-health officials.&#160;</li><li><strong>September 26: </strong>Trump nominated Judge Amy Coney Barrett at the White House in an event that has now been considered a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/timeline-white-house-coronavirus-outbreak-unfolded-2020-10#saturday-september-26-president-trump-hosts-an-event-in-the-rose-garden-to-formally-announce-his-nomination-of-amy-coney-barrett-to-the-supreme-court-1\">superspreader for the virus</a>, with more than 10 people testing positive afterward.</li></ul><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 11:32:40","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:32:40","title":"McConnell said he hasn't visited the White House in over 2 months because he doesn't think Trump's COVID-19 protocols are safe","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/mcconnell-hasnt-been-white-house-2-months-covid-19-rules-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7f6078d5f23d00195951b2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Mitch McConnell mask\" height=\"2169\" width=\"4339\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY) puts on a mask after speaking to the press\n<p class=\"copyright\">Drew Angerer/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell on Thursday said he has not been to the White House since August 6, citing the Trump administration's lax COVID-19 protocols.&#160;</li>\n<li>\"My impression was their approach to how to handle this was different than mine and what I insisted that we do in the Senate, which is to wear a mask and practice social distancing,\" McConnell said.</li>\n<li>The White House is dealing with a COVID-19 outbreak that's seen dozens of people contract the virus, including President Donald Trump.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell on Thursday said he has not been to the White House in more than two months, suggesting that the Trump administration's lax COVID-19 protocols make him feel unsafe.&#160;</p><p>The Kentucky Republican said that since early August he's instead opted to speak with President Donald Trump by phone.</p><p>\"I actually haven't been to the White House since August the 6th because my impression was their approach to how to handle this was different than mine and what I insisted that we do in the Senate, which is to wear a mask and practice social distancing,\" <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/watch/live/?v=371288537358499&ref=watch_permalinklink\">McConnell said at an event in Kentucky</a>.&#160;</p><p>Trump is currently infected with COVID-19 and the White House is dealing with an outbreak that's seen <a href=\"https://www.politico.com/news/2020/10/02/trump-white-house-coronavirus-positive-425229#stepien\">at least 35 people contract the virus</a>. The list of those who've been infected includes the first lady and a number of top aides to the president.&#160;&#160;</p><p>The infections are largely suspected to be linked to a Sept. 26 event at the Rose Garden where Trump announced that he was nominating Amy Coney Barrett for the Supreme Court. Many attendees could be seen without masks and there was a lack of social distancing. A number of those who went to the event, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/utah-sen-mike-lee-tests-positive-for-coronavirus-2020-10\">including Republican senators</a>, have since tested positive.&#160;</p><p>Though Trump was diagnosed with COVID-19 just a week ago, he's already back in the Oval Office despite the fact that he could still be contagious. Trump spent the weekend at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center, where he was transferred after his condition worsened last Friday. The <a href=\"https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/if-you-are-sick/end-home-isolation.html\">Centers for Disease Control and Prevention</a> says a person with COVID-19 should not be around other people for at least 10 days after symptoms first appear.&#160;</p><p>Trump downplayed the threat of COVID-19 for months prior to contracting the virus, and flouted public health recommendations such as wearing a mask and staying six feet away from others. Just two days before he tested positive, the president mocked former Vice President Joe Biden during the first presidential debate for routinely wearing a mask.&#160;</p><p>It's unclear whether <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/biden-solo-town-hall-trump-backed-out-virtual-presidential-debate-2020-10\">the next two presidential debates</a> will happen given that Trump has the virus and he rejected the possibility of holding a virtual debate to ensure everyone's safety.&#160;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/XjwjVMwshL4\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 08 Oct 2020 19:06:47 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f57d56e7ed0ee001e25e044?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"4df59f5b2a2d3bc6da19a71638003558","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn52@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-23-002_79dbd30900060b76.webp","destWidth":3853,"destHeight":2890,"sourceBytes":1404774,"destBytes":1404774,"author":"insider@insider.com (John Haltiwanger)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f7f6078d5f23d00195951b2?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn28@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-28-998_89f225fee6533d0e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=XjwjVMwshL4:xOYolyZIQxg:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn23@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-31-033_2940339e41ea1152.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=XjwjVMwshL4:xOYolyZIQxg:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn57@2020_1/2020/10/09/03-33-31-307_abf1512c093c2288.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn41@2020_4/2020/10/09/03-33-30-246_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=XjwjVMwshL4:xOYolyZIQxg:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn5@2020_2/2020/10/09/03-33-27-901_debd44751ae1b8b8.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/XjwjVMwshL4":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn64@2020_1/2020/10/09/03-33-32-579_86ec068a210680ef.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602214360898},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:32:40","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:32:40","title":"From an executive shakeup to a $400 million fine from regulators: Here's all you need to know about tumultuous times at Citigroup","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/citi-latest-news-fine-corbat-risk-management-occ-regulators-consent-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7f245f282c500018c7952e?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Michael Corbat\" height=\"2699\" width=\"3599\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Michael Corbat, Citi&#39;s CEO\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"http://www.apimages.com/metadata/Index/Citi-DC-Branch-Ribbon-Cutting/9c85ea8d70b5441eb2df89aaae0839be/10/0\" target=\"_blank\">Larry French/AP</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>On Wednesday, US regulators announced $400 million in fines against Citigroup for \"related to deficiencies in enterprise-wide risk management, compliance risk management, data governance, and internal controls.\"</li>\n<li>It's the latest in what has been a volatile few weeks for the global bank, which announced a change in leadership in September.</li>\n<li>Business Insider has previously reported on issues regulators had with Citi's inability to fix risk, compliance, and tech systems.&#160;&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><section><p>It's been a complicated month for Citigroup.</p><p>The third-biggest US bank by assets shocked Wall Street in September when it announced Michael Corbat, Citi's chief executive, would be retiring in February.</p><p>Jane Fraser, the bank's president and CEO of its consumer banking division, was named Corbat's successor, making her the first woman to serve as the chief executive of a major US bank.</p><p>However, it wasn't the selection of Fraser, who had been seen by many as Corbat's eventual successor after she was promoted to president of the bank last fall, that turned heads.</p><p>Instead, it was the timing of the announcement that raised questions. Corbat was only 60, leading some to believe he would remain at the helm of Citi longer. Analysts said the timing of the announcement was <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/citigroup-ceo-michael-corbat-to-retire-jane-fraser-president-replacement-2020-9\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">surprising and unexpected</a>. The bank was also only a few months removed from an erroneous $900 million wire.&#160;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f5cb650e6ff30001d4e87a1?format=jpeg\" alt=\"jane fraser\" height=\"750\" width=\"1000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Jane Fraser, Citi&#39;s president and CEO of its consumer banking division\n<p class=\"copyright\">Julian Restrepo/Citigroup via AP</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>On Wednesday, less than a month after the announcement of Corbat's retirement, the <a href=\"https://www.federalreserve.gov/newsevents/pressreleases/enforcement20201007a.htm\">Federal Reserve Board</a> and <a href=\"https://www.occ.gov/news-issuances/news-releases/2020/nr-occ-2020-132.html\">Office of the Comptroller of the Currency</a>&#160;announced <a href=\"https://www.occ.gov/news-issuances/news-releases/2020/nr-occ-2020-132.html\">$400 million</a> in fines levied against Citi \"related to deficiencies in enterprise-wide risk management, compliance risk management, data governance, and internal controls,\" according to the OCC.&#160;</p><p>In addition to the fine, Citigroup needs to check with the OCC prior making significant new acquisitions. The regulator can also make changes or restrictions to the bank's senior management and board if \"timely, sufficient progress\" is not made.</p><p>Read more about the runup to Fraser's appointment, including the underlying issues Citi was facing with regulators in the lead-up to this week's announcement:</p><p>&#160;</p><h2><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/citigroup-ceo-michael-corbat-to-retire-jane-fraser-president-replacement-2020-9?r=citi-teaser\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Wall Street shatters a glass ceiling as Jane Fraser is announced as Citigroup's new CEO, becoming the first woman to lead a major US bank</a></h2><p>&#160;</p><section><h2><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/citigroup-spending-1-billion-to-shore-up-risk-management-controls-2020-9?r=citi-teaser\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Citi's CFO says the bank is shrinking its office footprint and moving people to lower-cost locations to help keep expenses in check</a></h2><p>&#160;</p><section><section><h2><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/inside-real-reasons-behind-citi-mike-corbat-early-retirement-2020-9?r=citi-teaser\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">The real reasons behind Citigroup CEO Mike Corbat's retirement</a></h2></section><section></section><p>&#160;</p><section><h2><a +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f7f5f2bd5f23d00195951ad?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"82564a5124f893144437861c73e45a8c","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn4@2020_3/2020/10/09/03-33-23-345_e9ef844bf84621f9.webp","destWidth":2959,"destHeight":2219,"sourceBytes":558850,"destBytes":558850,"author":"insider@insider.com (Business Insider)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f7f245f282c500018c7952e?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn25@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-24-651_f07daf7c7f91e116.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f5cb650e6ff30001d4e87a1?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn76@2020_2/2020/10/09/03-33-33-976_6edb1edca8b826f2.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=2QZIuOiCFxg:oEuMGJ9sHF4:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn83@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-31-389_48f4c15e48e16edc.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=2QZIuOiCFxg:oEuMGJ9sHF4:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn43@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-28-914_d12bb38e49375a8c.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn41@2020_4/2020/10/09/03-33-30-246_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=2QZIuOiCFxg:oEuMGJ9sHF4:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn51@2020_3/2020/10/09/03-33-31-939_af8db6b92a1c5c36.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/2QZIuOiCFxg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn6@2020_4/2020/10/09/03-33-33-534_97c887b71d7a4d16.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602214360901},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:32:40","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:32:40","title":"Facebook removed hundreds of fake accounts linked to conservative youth group Turning Point USA that used the platform to spread pro-Trump messages","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/facebook-removes-fake-accounts-linked-to-turning-point-usa-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7f4048c655f6001969efab?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Facebook headquarters\" height=\"1466\" width=\"1955\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Elijah Nouvelage/Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Facebook has removed 200 fake accounts created by a marketing firm that was working for an affiliate of conservative youth group Turning Point USA.&#160;</li>\n<li>The company announced that it had discovered a coordinated campaign to use fake accounts to comment on news articles, writing messages centered around topics like the coronavirus outbreak and the 2020 election.</li>\n<li>In examples published by Facebook, commenters criticized mail-in ballots, promoted big game hunting, and said Democrats \"will do anything to screw over Americans.\"&#160;</li>\n<li>Facebook said it discovered the campaign after <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/turning-point-teens-disinformation-trump/2020/09/15/c84091ae-f20a-11ea-b796-2dd09962649c_story.html\">reporting from the Washington Post</a> last month found that the affiliate group, Turning Point Action, was paying teenagers to post pro-Trump messages.&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Facebook has removed hundreds of fake accounts created by a marketing firm working for Turning Point Action, an affiliate of pro-Trump youth group Turning Point USA, <a href=\"https://about.fb.com/news/2020/10/removing-coordinated-inauthentic-behavior-september-report/\">the company announced Thursday</a>.&#160;</p><p>Facebook said it identified a coordinated campaign to create fake accounts that commented on other people's posts after the <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/turning-point-teens-disinformation-trump/2020/09/15/c84091ae-f20a-11ea-b796-2dd09962649c_story.html\">Washington Post's Isaac Stanley-Becker reported last month</a> about a campaign to pump out conservative messages on the platform. Since then, Facebook said it's identified 200 fake accounts tied to Rally Forge, a marketing agency that it said was working on behalf of Turning Point USA, as well as an organization called Inclusive Conservation Group. Facebook said it has now banned Rally Forge from the platform.&#160;</p><p>In a statement to Business Insider, Turning Point Action clarified it had been running the campaign, not Turning Point USA.</p><p>\"Facebook's blog post in question was in reference to a project for Turning Point Action, a 501c4 and an entirely separate entity. The mistake has been flagged with Facebook's communication team,\" the statement read. \"Turning Point Action works hard to operate within social platforms' TOS on all of its projects and communications and we hope to work closely with Facebook to rectify any misunderstanding.\"</p><p>A spokesperson for Rally Forge did not immediately respond to Business Insider's request for comment.&#160;</p><p>In its report, Facebook described how, beginning in 2018, fake accounts using stock profile pictures posed mostly as right-leaning people based in the US and commented on articles posted by high-profile individuals or news agencies.</p><p>The comments centered around topics like the 2018 midterm elections, the 2020 presidential election, the coronavirus outbreak, and trophy hunting, as well as praise for President Donald Trump and the Republican party and criticism about former Vice President Joe Biden and the Democratic party.&#160;</p><p>The accounts have recently focused their activity on the Facebook pages of The New York Times, the Washington Post, Fox News, CNN, and MSNBC, Facebook said.&#160;</p><p>In examples published by Facebook, commenters criticized mail-in ballots, promoted big game hunting, and said Democrats \"will do anything to screw over Americans.\"&#160;</p><p>Facebook said that after the fake accounts were caught by its detection systems, the campaign changed tactics to create more realistic accounts that used names similar to the people behind the accounts — Facebook calls them \"thinly veiled personas.\"&#160;</p><p>Their \"sole activity on our platform was associated with this deceptive campaign,\" Facebook said.&#160;</p><p>In addition to the coordinated comments, Facebook took down 55 pages and 75 Instagram accounts associated with the campaign. All told, the associated accounts spent $973,000 on ads on both Facebook and Instagram.</p><p>Turning Point USA is a conservative activist group founded by Charlie Kirk, a 26-year-old who <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/rnc-covid-19-pandemic-takes-back-seat-to-culture-wars-2020-8\">spoke at this year's Republican National Convention</a>. According to <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/turning-point-teens-disinformation-trump/2020/09/15/c84091ae-f20a-11ea-b796-2dd09962649c_story.html\">the Post's report</a> from last month, Turning Point Action paid teenagers to post messages on Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter that mirror talking points from Trump's re-election campaign. The messages included misleading or outright false claims, and the users did not disclose their relationship with Turning Point Action, the Post reported.&#160;</p><p>Turning Point Action's field director, Austin Smith, told the Post at the time that the campaign was \"sincere political activism conducted by real people who passionately hold the beliefs they describe online\" and shouldn't be compared to a troll farm.&#160;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/facebook-removes-fake-accounts-linked-to-turning-point-usa-2020-10'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a Hartmans)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f7f4048c655f6001969efab?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn55@2020_4/2020/10/09/03-33-33-769_6d975c528fadb034.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=S4W-OhWEQ50:DtGb5pqtC7c:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn8@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-35-019_9a9d6c6ab005de32.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=S4W-OhWEQ50:DtGb5pqtC7c:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn80@2020_6/2020/10/09/03-33-27-776_fcdec87e8a595561.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn41@2020_4/2020/10/09/03-33-30-246_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=S4W-OhWEQ50:DtGb5pqtC7c:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn73@2020_6/2020/10/09/03-33-32-744_695e042e5b819f71.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/S4W-OhWEQ50":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn1@2020_1/2020/10/09/03-33-26-986_d0413cdb33442998.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602214360902},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:32:40","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:32:40","title":"Lime's CEO explains how the scooter company's 'near death experience' during the pandemic helped set it up to turn a profit next year","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/lime-ceo-pandemic-pivot-company-on-track-turn-profit-2021-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7f6dcfea74820019ca6096?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Wayne Ting, CEO, Lime\" height=\"3648\" width=\"5472\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Wayne Ting, a four-year Uber veteran, took over as Lime&#39;s CEO in May amid the pandemic.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Lime</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Lime's bike and scooter revenues plunged 95% when the pandemic hit in the spring, CEO Wayne Ting told Business Insider..&#160;</li>\n<li>But it's come out stronger than ever thanks to a pivot to become a one-stop app for any and all electric vehicles to get around.&#160;</li>\n<li>Ting says the company is on track to turn a profit for the first time next year. It could be one of the first micro-mobility companies to do so.&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Lime's new CEO had his work cut out for him when he took over in May.</p><p>As the coronavirus pandemic brought virtually all travel to a standstill, the scooter and bike-rental company's revenues quickly fell more than 95%, CEO Wayne Ting told Business Insider in an interview. But thanks to a shift in focus&#160; — and a buzzy deal with Uber to take over the ride-hailing firm's micro-mobility suite — the company says it's on track to turn a profit next year.</p><p>\"Our vision for Lime is to be <em>the</em> platform for mobility under five miles,\" said Ting, who spent four years at Uber before joining Lime in May. \"If you're in a city and are going from point A to point B, we want you to open the Lime app and know you can get there using the mode at the price point that you want.\"</p><p>He doesn't care if that's on a Lime scooter, a Jump bike, or the app's newest offering: a Wheels-branded sit-down scooter, available in four US cities this winter with more to follow. Every new vehicle, Ting says, helps Lime find new riders that might be averse to their original stand-up scooter for one reason or another.</p><p>\"Our main scooter product is very popular with younger people, and with slightly more men than women,\" Ting said. \"But with eBikes, for example, we see people who are older, we see more women riders than men riders.\"</p><p>After all, whether you're sitting or standing, \"the actual underlying technology isn't that different.\"</p><p>That should take some of the frustration out of arriving in a city, seeing a handful of differently branded vehicles, and having to choose which new app to download and use to move around. After an explosion of new micro-mobility companies, flush with venture capital cash, launched in recent years, Lime expects to see further consolidation similar to Uber's exit earlier this year.</p><p>\"I think 2020 into 2021 is a turning point for micro-mobility,\" Ting said. \"Covid was a near-death experience for a lot of us. But all of the trends underlying the growth of micro-mobility feel like they're going faster.\"</p><p>Specifically, he pointed to electrification, which is happening from bikes and scooters all the way to full-size cars. California, notably, has announced plans to <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/california-to-ban-sale-of-new-gasoline-powered-passenger-vehicles-in-2035-2020-9\">prohibit the sale of new internal combustion-powered automobiles</a> after 2035. The sharing economy, he also said, should continue to grow alongside Uber, Lyft, Airbnb, and a whole host of other platforms.</p><p>\"Historically in this industry, if you look at the amount of money that's flowed into it and the amount of money that it appears to have lost,\" Ting said. \"It seems staggering. I think one of the great things about Covid and the moment we've gone through, is it's forced companies to get better and think about the long term.\"</p><p>\"The people who can't get serious about building a great business,\" he continued, \"sometimes don't make it through.\"</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a
